awd_titl_txt: Combining Academic Support and Service Learning to Support Success of Undergraduates in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics Fields
awd_abstract_narration:
The NSF Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (S-STEM) program supports the retention and graduation of high-achieving, low-income students pursuing STEM degrees. In this project, Loras College will award scholarships of up to $10,000 per year to high-achieving students with demonstrated financial need. The awards are renewable up to three times and the college anticipates supporting two groups of 9-10 students throughout the five years of the project. To support student success, the principal investigator (PI) team will coordinate a suite of academic support services together with community-based service learning opportunities. By building such opportunities into its curriculum, Loras College seeks to help southern Iowa, and the Nation more broadly, recruit and graduate additional STEM students.  These graduates can contribute to critical regional and national workforce demands. 

The project aims to provide financial, academic, career planning, and social support for students considering STEM degrees, in concert with creating a cohort model and community-based learning opportunities. The project's twin pedagogical approaches (academic support services and the community-based learning model) have proven successful at other institutions. However, this project is innovative in implementing and assessing this combination of approaches. Scholarship recipients will enroll in a series of one-credit courses designed to develop their scientific identities. Through these courses, students will participate in activities to support two critical transitions: from high-school to college and from college into the workforce. Academic support will include mentoring by engaged faculty, peer support, and training in academic success skills, such as time management, test taking strategies, and studying approaches. The project will also provide social support through professional events, shared community events, and bridging activities. Finally, the investigators will organize tours of local industry and group community-based research and design projects. Effectiveness of this program will be evaluated using survey and quantitative data. The educational resources and research results will be disseminated through regional and national publications, in presentations at professional meetings, and at annual reports to NSF and the college.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Loras College partnered with the NSF S-STEM program, creating and researching a unique STEM pathway for academically talented, low-income students with demonstrated financial need by launching the DuSTEM program (named after the College mascot, the "Duhawk").  Research findings state that necessary for success in STEM fields are academic ability as well as financial, academic, and community support. The DuSTEM program will provide these supports by providing scholarships and targeted experiences.  The project builds on Loras’ already successful recruitment, retention, and graduation rates in these disciplines. The plan is to further widen the recruitment funnel to include more for whom a scholarship will make college possible, while also attracting students who are currently undecided, but demonstrate ability and interest alignment.

DuSTEM had the following goals: Increase enrollment in Computer Science, Chemistry, Engineering and Mathematics by 18 students, or an average of 28% annually; increase retention for students in targeted majors by an average rate of 43% based on intended major on their application; increase the number of graduates from these majors by 28%; and determine the impact of the community support and community-based learning projects in attaining the above goals.

DuSTEM included a wide variety of supports beyond scholarships.  A two-semester, one-hour a week seminar course was designed for first-year DuSTEM students.  It introduced students to numerous professional development topics, including presentation skills, job search skills, and skills relating to emotional intelligence such as training on Imposter Syndrome, Grit, and Self-Affirmation.  It also included panel discussions with older STEM students, Loras STEM faculty, and STEM faculty and professionals off-campus.  This course focused on developing their STEM identity and community. 

Addition financial support was provided to DuSTEM students to assist in travel, for example to Women in Engineering annual conference, the American Chemical Society’s national conference, the S-STEM student leadership conference, and the Lockheed-Martin’s Engineering Ethics Competition.  Financial support also supported research and independent projects.  Further non-financial support was provided in the form of mentoring by faculty and the availability of academic support services specifically in challenging introductory and intermediate level STEM courses.

The program was successful in meeting the goals of increasing enrollment, retention and graduation of students in particular in Computer Science and Engineering. While other STEM majors at the college have experienced consistent enrollments, the numbers of Computer Science students has doubled and the numbers of students in Engineering have more than tripled in size. The growth in the number of students has allowed the Engineering program to expand, adding another faculty member as well as a full Mechanical Engineering major. The success of this project further highlights the importance of students being able to apply scientific theory outside of the traditional classroom.  Students respond to these experiences by persisting in STEM majors at a greater rate than their peers. Due to the success of the program in meeting its goals, Loras College has decided to continue the program with slight changes to continue to build program’s achievements.



Last Modified: 07/16/2024
Modified by: Kristen A Thompson
